hanūz ik partav-e naqsh-e ḳhayāl-e yār bāqī
hai
secondVerse:
dil-e afsurdah goyā ḥujrah hai yūsuf
ke zindāñ kā
engTranslation:
1) still/now a single/particular/unique/excellent ray of the 
      picture/print of the thought of the beloved is left

      2) the chilled/sad heart is, so to speak, a chamber of the prison of Joseph
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {10}
sherText:
hanūz ik partav-e naqsh-e ḳhayāl-e yār bāqī
hai
dil-e afsurdah goyā ḥujrah hai yūsuf
ke zindāñ kā

engTranslation:
1) entirely whole-mirror-possessing of brokenness/breakingness--

      2) I am the desire/intention of those with a whole-worldful of dejection
interpretation: Here, by afsurdagāñ is meant those people who have become dejected by not succeeding in their purposes-- when they form a desire/intention of something, they see nothing but failure upon failure in every direction. Ghalib gives himself as a simile for this failed desire/intention. The result is that 'I am the embodiment of failure and nonachievement'.
sherText:
sarāpā yak-āʾīnah-dār-e shikastan

      irādah hūñ yak-ʿālam-afsurdagāñ kā

engTranslation:
1) it did not forget the restlessness of {breath/moment}-counting, our waiting

      2) for finally it served as an hour-glass, our dust
notes: sāʿat : 'Time; at hour; a short time, a little while; a minute; a moment; —a clock, a watch'. (Platts p.625)
interpretation: The meaning is that the habit I had in life of counting the hours of separation did not depart even after I had died and become dust, and from my dust an hour-glass was made. Because of the continuous falling of the grains, the hour-glass has been given the simile of restlessness, and the cause of similitude is movement. (44)
sherText:
nah bhūlā iẓt̤irāb-e dam-shumārī intiz̤ār apnā

kih āḳhir shīshah-e sāʿat ke kām āyā ġhubār apnā

interpretation: It is astonishing that the selection-makers neglected/overlooked this verse. Probably they neglected it because they considered shauq-e dīdār , instead of shauq-e iz̤hār , to be meaningless, and thought that the poet had used that word only on the basis of his natural inclination toward the art of eloquence [whereas in fact the verse is mystically very subtle]. If Ghalib today had sat down to make a selection of his poetry, then he would never have plucked out and tossed aside such a good verse. And not only this one verse-- many, or most [unpublished] verses are such that they have been unjustly slain! (34)
sherText:
sāġhar-e jalvah-e sarshār hai har żarrah-e 
      ḳhāk

      shauq-e dīdār balā āʾinah-sāmāñ niklā

engTranslation:
1) Asad 
      is a stranger to coldness/dejection, oh Friendlessness/forlornness

      2) [his] heart, from the style of the warmth/fervor of the people of the 
      world, burned up
interpretation:
Oh Friendlessness, Asad is now not influenced by dejection. 
    He has seen the warmth and ebullience of the people of the world, and having 
    seen its artificialness and triviality his heart has burned. Now he has arrived 
    beyond the feeling of dejection. (110)
sherText:
hai asad be-gānah-e afsurdagī ay be-kasī

      dil z andāz-e tapāk-e ahl-e dunyā jal gayā

firstVerse:
żarrah żarrah sāġhar-e mai-ḳhānah-e 
      nairang hai

      gardish-e majnūñ bah chashmak'hā-e lailâ āshnā
engTranslation:
1) every sand-grain is a cup/glass of the wine-house 
      of fascination/magic

      2) the going-around of Majnun 
      is acquainted/familiar with the glances/winks of Laila
interpretation:
The way the going around of Majnun was in thrall to the 
    effects of Laila's eyes, in the same way every sand-grain of the world is 
    obedient to the fascination of the world. (41)
sherText:
żarrah żarrah sāġhar-e mai-ḳhānah-e 
      nairang hai

      gardish-e majnūñ bah chashmak'hā-e lailâ āshnā

firstVerse:
naqsh faryādī hai kis kī shoḳhī-e
              taḥrīr
              kā
secondVerse:
kāġhażī hai pairahan har paikar-e
              taṣvīr kā
engTranslation:
1) the drawing/picture is a plaintiff--
          about whose mischievousness of writing?

          2) of paper is the robe of every figure of/in the picture
interpretation:
[1865, to Shakir:] First listen to the meaning of the
        meaningless verses. As for naqsh faryādī :
        In Iran there is the custom that the seeker of justice [dād-ḳhvāh], putting on paper garments,
        goes before the ruler-- as in the case of lighting a torch in
        the day, or carrying a blood-soaked cloth on a bamboo pole [to
        protest an injustice]. Thus the poet reflects, of whose
        mischievousness of writing is the image a plaintiff? --since the
        aspect of a picture is that its garment is of paper. That is to
        say, although existence may be like that of pictures, merely
        notional [ětibār-e maḥaẓ], it is a
        cause of grief and sorrow and suffering.
sherText:
naqsh faryādī hai kis kī shoḳhī-e
              taḥrīr
              kā

            kāġhażī hai pairahan har paikar-e
              taṣvīr kā

engTranslation:
1) the polish-lines of a mirror are nothing except 
      the sign/wink/riddle of the tips of the eyelashes

      2) a friend understands the mutual/shared sign/hint of a friend
notes:
ramz : 'Sign, indication, nod, wink, hint, 
    insinuation, innuendo, ambiguous expression, double entendre, mysterious allusion, 
    riddle, enigma; sarcasm, irony'. (Platts p.599)
interpretation: Perhaps the point of these signs might be that the eyelashes would look sharply at the lover, and would ensnare the mirror in a net of polish-lines. Or else that the way the polish-lines are attractive, in the same way the eyelashes are attractive and are the polish-lines of the mirror of beauty; therefore in signs they both praise each other. In any case, these expressions must be considered the measure of the verse, so that its meanings would be fulfilled. (66)
sherText:
jauhar-e āʾīnah juz ramz-e sar-e mizhgāñ 
      nahīñ 

      āshnā kī ham-digar samjhe hai īmā āshnā

firstVerse: dil diyā jān ke kyūñ us ko vafādār asad
secondVerse: ġhalat̤ī kī kih jo kāfir ko musalmāñ samjhā
engTranslation:
1) why did you give your heart, considering her faithful, 
      Asad?

      2) you made an error, in that you considered an infidel [to be] a Muslim
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {34}
sherText:
dil diyā jān ke kyūñ us ko vafādār asad

      ġhalat̤ī kī kih jo kāfir ko musalmāñ samjhā

firstVerse:
yūsuf us ko kahūñ aur kuchh nah 
      kahe ḳhair huʾī

      gar bigaṛ baiṭhe to maiñ lāʾiq-e taʿzīr bhī thā
engTranslation:
1) if I would call her 'Yusuf' 
      and she would say nothing-- wellbeing occurred!

      2) if she would insist on quarreling, then I was even/also worthy of punishment
notes:
ḳhair : 'Good; goodness; benefit; good 
    fortune, prosperity, welfare, well-being, weal; health; happiness'. (Platts 
    p.498)
interpretation:
He says, I called her Yusuf (that is, made her into a slave); 
    it was very fortunate that, hearing this praise from me, she fell silent. 
    If she had become angry, then I deserved punishment for calling her Yusuf. 
    (71)
sherText:
yūsuf us ko kahūñ aur kuchh nah 
      kahe ḳhair huʾī

      gar bigaṛ baiṭhe to maiñ lāʾiq-e taʿzīr bhī thā

firstVerse:
kam jānte the ham bhī ġham-e ʿishq ko par
ab
secondVerse:
dekhā to kam huʾe pah ġham-e rozgār
thā
engTranslation:
1a) we too considered the grief of passion [to be 
      relatively] less/small, but now

      1b) we too knew little of the grief of passion, but now
interpretation:
Because of inexperience, like others I too thought that the 
    grief of passion was small. But when I was trapped in that disaster, I became 
    aware of the true state of affairs. That is, the grief of passion, even when 
    it becomes less, turned out to be somewhat more than the whole world's grief. 
    (36)
sherText:
kam jānte the ham bhī ġham-e ʿishq ko par
ab
dekhā to kam huʾe pah ġham-e rozgār
thā

firstVerse:
qaid meñ hai tire vaḥshī ko vuhī 
      zulf kī yād

      hāñ kuchh-ik ranj-e girāñ-bārī-e zanjīr bhī thā
engTranslation:
1) in shackles/bondage, your wild one has that same memory of curls

      2) indeed/yes, there was even/also some small trouble/pain/vexation 
      of the heaviness of the chains
notes:
qaid : 'A shackle, fetter, bonds; bondage; 
    confinement, imprisonment; control; restraint; restriction'. (Platts pp.796-97)
interpretation:
He says, your madman has still not forgotten your curls, 
    by which he had previously been imprisoned. Although along with it, he also 
    had a light thought of the heaviness of the chains also. Through this mention, 
    he wanted to show that the imprisonment in chains is less in harshness than 
    the imprisonment of the curls. (70)
sherText:
qaid meñ hai tire vaḥshī ko vuhī 
      zulf kī yād

      hāñ kuchh-ik ranj-e girāñ-bārī-e zanjīr bhī thā

firstVerse: dil us ko pahle hī nāz-o-adā se de baiṭhe
secondVerse: hameñ dimāġh kahāñ ḥusn ke taqāẓā kā
engTranslation:
1a) from/through the very first airs and graces, we 
      gave over our heart to her

      1b)
      even before the airs and graces, we gave over our heart to her

      

      2a) how/where would we have a mind/desire for the claim/dunning/importunity 
      of beauty? 

      2b) as if we would have a mind/desire for the claim/dunning/importunity 
      of beauty!
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {27}
sherText:
dil us ko pahle hī nāz-o-adā se de baiṭhe
hameñ dimāġh kahāñ ḥusn ke taqāẓā kā

engTranslation:
1a) in appearance-- formality/courtesy; 
      in reality-- grief/regret

      1b) with the face/appearance of formality/courtesy, with the 
      reality of grief/regret,

      

      2) Asad, I am the smile 
      of the withered/blighted ones
notes:
maʿnī : 'Meaning, intended sense, intent, 
    signification; indication, import, drift, acceptation; intrinsic quality; 
    --spirituality; --substance, essence; reality; the interior or hidden part 
    (of anything)'. (Platts p.1050)
interpretation: The way dejected people, for the sake of their companions, would even smile-- that smile will be artificial. It will look like a smile/laugh, but it will be the same as a thousand tear-sheddings. (61)
sherText:
bah ṣūrat takalluf bah maʿnī taʾassuf

      asad maiñ tabassum hūñ pazhmurdagāñ kā

engTranslation:
1) entirely whole-mirror-possessing of brokenness/breakingness--

      2) I am the desire/intention of those with a whole-worldful of dejection
interpretation: Here, by afsurdagāñ is meant those people who have become dejected by not succeeding in their purposes-- when they form a desire/intention of something, they see nothing but failure upon failure in every direction. Ghalib gives himself as a simile for this failed desire/intention. The result is that 'I am the embodiment of failure and nonachievement'.
sherText:
sarāpā yak-āʾīnah-dār-e shikastan

      irādah hūñ yak-ʿālam-afsurdagāñ kā

firstVerse:
shumār-e subḥah marġhūb-e but-e 
mushkil-pasand āyā
secondVerse: tamāshā-e bah yak-kaf burdan-e ṣad dil pasand āyā
engTranslation:
1) the counting of the prayer-beads was enjoyable to
the difficulty-loving idol
2) the spectacle
of the holding of a hundred hearts in one hand pleased her
notes: marġhūb : 'Desired; —desirable; agreeable; amiable; lovely, beautiful; estimable, excellent'. (Platts p.1023)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {8}
sherText:
shumār-e subḥah marġhūb-e but-e 
mushkil-pasand āyā
tamāshā-e bah yak-kaf burdan-e ṣad dil pasand āyā

firstVerse:
le gaʾe ḳhāk meñ ham dāġh-e tamannā-e
nashāt̤
secondVerse:
tū ho aur āp bah ṣad-rang
gulistāñ honā
engTranslation:
1) we took away into the dust the wound of the longing for growth/vitality/joy

2) you be! [imperative], and [your]self must be a garden with
a hundred colors
notes: nashāt̤ : 'Liveliness, sprightliness, cheerfulness,    gladness, glee, joy, pleasure, exultation, triumph'.  (Platts p.1139)
interpretation:
That is, you have killed the people of desire by keeping 
    them in a state of longing. Now, be the only observer of your own springtime.... 
    bah ṣad-rang gulistāñ honā should be considered a translation of 
    [the Persian] ṣad rang bahār shiguftan [which means] 
    'an extremely flourishing spring'.
sherText:
le gaʾe ḳhāk meñ ham dāġh-e tamannā-e
nashāt̤
tū ho aur āp bah ṣad-rang
gulistāñ honā

firstVerse:
nah de nāle ko itnā t̤ūl ġhālib muḳhtaṣar likh
de
secondVerse:
kih ḥasrat-sanj hūñ ʿarẓ-e sitamhā-e
judāʾī kā
engTranslation:
1) don't give the lament/complaint so much length, 
      Ghalib, write {an abstract / briefly}

      2) that 'I am a longing-measurer of the breadth/petition of the 
      tyrannies of separation'
notes: ḥasrat : 'Grief, regret, intense grief or sorrow; —longing, desire'. (Platts p.477)
interpretation:
He says, 'Oh Ghalib, when you lengthen the letter by writing 
    all kinds of laments and all types of complaints, what's the point? Write 
    a shortish sentence, that I have in my heart a longing to express the tyrannies 
    of separation and the suffering of being apart.' (51)
sherText:
nah de nāle ko itnā t̤ūl ġhālib muḳhtaṣar likh
de
kih ḥasrat-sanj hūñ ʿarẓ-e sitamhā-e
judāʾī kā

firstVerse:
tamannā-e zabāñ maḥv-e sipās-e be-zabānī
hai
secondVerse:
miṭā jis se taqāẓā shikvah-e
be-dast-o-pāʾī kā
engTranslation:
1) the longing of/for the tongue is absorbed in the 
      praise/thanks of/for tonguelessness

      2) through which was erased the claim/demand of/for the complaint of helplessness/'hand-and-footless-ness'
notes:
sipās : 'Praise, thanksgiving'. (Platts 
    p.634)
interpretation:
He says, my longing is this too: that I would ask from you 
    a tongue such that I would be able to use it in your court for expressing 
    my situation. But before this plea or prayer, my tongue became absorbed in 
    the praise of tonguelessness. That is, because I didn't receive that special 
    tongue, there was the benefit that I wasn't able to present in your court 
    the complaint of helplessness. And from that there was the benefit that in 
    place of a tongue of complaint, the rank of acceptance and contentment was 
    bestowed upon me. (50)
sherText:
tamannā-e zabāñ maḥv-e sipās-e be-zabānī
hai
miṭā jis se taqāẓā shikvah-e
be-dast-o-pāʾī kā

engTranslation:
1) the wildness of the dream/sleep of nonexistence is the tumult of the spectacle, Asad

      2) apart from eyelashes, there are no polish-lines on the mirror of (dream-)interpretation
notes: shor : 'Cry, noise, outcry, exclamation, din, clamour, uproar, tumult, disturbance'. (Platts p.736)
interpretation: By 'mirror of interpretation' is meant the eyes; and by the eyelashes not being interpreted as polish-lines on the mirror is meant the eyelashes not closing; by 'tumult of the spectacle' is meant the tumult of the spectacle-place of existence.
sherText:
vaḥshat-e ḳhvāb-e ʿadam shor-e tamāshā hai asad

juz mizhah jauhar nahīñ āʾīnah-e taʿbīr kā

firstVerse:
gilah hai shauq ko dil meñ bhī tangī-e jā
kā
secondVerse:
guhar meñ maḥv huʾā iẓt̤irāb
daryā kā
engTranslation:
1) ardor complains, even/also in the heart, of narrowness 
      of place 

      2) in a pearl became absorbed/annihilated the restlessness of the sea
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {27}
sherText:
gilah hai shauq ko dil meñ bhī tangī-e jā
kā
guhar meñ maḥv huʾā iẓt̤irāb
daryā kā

engTranslation:
1) the polish-lines of a mirror are nothing except 
      the sign/wink/riddle of the tips of the eyelashes

      2) a friend understands the mutual/shared sign/hint of a friend
notes:
samjhe hai is an archaic form of samajhtā 
    hai (GRAMMAR)
interpretation: Perhaps the point of these signs might be that the eyelashes would look sharply at the lover, and would ensnare the mirror in a net of polish-lines. Or else that the way the polish-lines are attractive, in the same way the eyelashes are attractive and are the polish-lines of the mirror of beauty; therefore in signs they both praise each other. In any case, these expressions must be considered the measure of the verse, so that its meanings would be fulfilled. (66)
sherText:
jauhar-e āʾīnah juz ramz-e sar-e mizhgāñ 
      nahīñ 

      āshnā kī ham-digar samjhe hai īmā āshnā

firstVerse:
kiyā āʾīnah-ḳhāne kā vuh naqshah tere jalve
ne
secondVerse: kare jo partav-e ḳhvurshīd ʿālam shabnamistāñ kā
engTranslation:
1) your glory/appearance made of the mirror-chamber 
      that picture/aspect/state--

      2) the scene/aspect/state that a ray of the sun would make of a land of dew
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {10}
sherText:
kiyā āʾīnah-ḳhāne kā vuh naqshah tere jalve
ne

      kare jo partav-e ḳhvurshīd ʿālam shabnamistāñ kā

engTranslation:
1) if  piety is the experiencing of the rounds of the houses of generous ones

      2) like a bead of the prayer-beads, I became a piece/bead that was checkmated/perplexed
notes: muhrah : 'A bead (of glass, or coral); ... —a piece, or man (at chess, backgammon, &c.); a counter (for playing any game)'. (Platts p.1100)
interpretation: That is, the going-around of the beads in the prayer-beads of the pious ones amazed me, and I arrived at the conclusion that through piety those people's goal was to circumambulate [t̤avāf karnā] the houses of important men (and also to ask for alms there), and everything else was trivial. But this conclusion-- that the moving of the beads of prayer-beads has the special goal of circumambulating the houses of the rich-- was not a  correct, sound conclusion.
sherText:

interpretation: He has imagined madness as a world of madness, and in that capacity has called it a workshop where madmen are steadily created and sent forth. Then he has reflected that at the time when the madmen are created, it's necessary that their clothing would be removed; for this reason there must be heaps of torn-up garment-hems and collars lying around. But this idea was incorrect. After experience, he says that he went into a workshop where there ought to be no shortage of garment-hems and collars-- but look at the ill-fortune, that even there he obtained not even a single torn collar! ....

He says, ardor for self-display has opened the ties of the

    see it. Thus it's been said that except for sight, no veil remains between 
    them. If the outer eye would open, then the outward veils can be lifted. (77)

    grace, favour, graciousness, generosity, benevolence, gentleness, amenity'. 
    (Platts p.957)
interpretation:
ṭapaktā hai means 'is apparent'. 
    The blood of the slaughtered one is flowing swiftly, making waves. Meanwhile 
    the murderer, having murdered him, had run headlong away. It seems that the 
    the murderer's style of fleeing has pleased the blood of the wounded one, 
    and it too is running in the same manner. (64)

He says, my longing is this too: that I would ask from you 
    a tongue such that I would be able to use it in your court for expressing

    tongue, there was the benefit that I wasn't able to present in your court 
    the complaint of helplessness. And from that there was the benefit that in 
    place of a tongue of complaint, the rank of acceptance and contentment was 
    bestowed upon me. (50)

hai mujhe abr-e bahārī kā baras 
      kar khulnā

      rote rote ġham-e furqat meñ fanā ho jānā
engTranslation:
1) to me, the raining/bursting and opening/unravelling 
      of the springtime rain-cloud is

      2) weeping and weeping, in the grief of separation, to become obliterated
interpretation: [July 29, 1862, to Majruh:] Speaking of the rainy season, first listen to an overview. There was the revolt of the blacks; then the tumult of the whites; then the disturbance of the demolition of houses; then the disaster of the epidemics; then the difficulty of the famine. Now this rainy season is all of them rolled into one. Today is the twenty-first day. The sun is visible here and there the way lightning flashes. At night, if sometimes the stars can be seen, people take them for fireflies. In the dark nights, thieves flourish. Not a day passes without news of burglaries at three or four houses. Don't think it's an exaggeration-- thousands of houses have collapsed, hundreds of people have been crushed to death. In every lane, a river flows. To make a long story short, the earlier famine was caused by the failure of the rains; grain did not grow. This one is a water-famine: so much rain fell that the sown seeds were washed away. Those who haven't yet sown, have held back from sowing. You've heard the state of things in Delhi. Other than this, there's nothing new.
sherText:
hai mujhe abr-e bahārī kā baras 
      kar khulnā

      rote rote ġham-e furqat meñ fanā ho jānā

engTranslation:
1) the 'heat' of wealth/fortune/dominion became fire-setting to a good/beautiful name

      2) in the 'house' of the signet-ring, the ruby of the ring became a spark
interpretation: In former times the name used to be engraved on the stone of a ring, so that it was used as a seal. So to speak, the stone of the ring was the cause of the fame/reputation of the name. ḳhānah-e ḳhātim = that circle of the ring in which the stone used to be set. The heat of wealth burnt up a good name like fire. An illustration is that when an expensive stone like a ruby was set into a ring, then it showed the aspect of fire. Since a ruby is only set into the rings of rich people, and it has a similitude with fire, the claim of the first line has been proved.
sherText:

      2a) having writhed in blood in a hundred ways/colors is a/the claim of purity

      2b) a/the claim of purity is, having writhed in blood in a hundred ways

engTranslation: 1) the ebullience of spring is a trouble to the gaze, Asad
notes: naz̤z̤ārah : 'Sight, view, look, show; inspection; —amorous glance, ogling'. (Platts p.1142)
interpretation: Springtime is always called a comfort/rest to the gaze. Ghalib, parting company with them all, called it a trouble to the gaze. In the second line, between the cloud and the cotton, which one would be established as the subject and which one as the predicate-- from that, various meanings emerge.

      1b) with the face/appearance of formality/courtesy, with the

      2) Asad, I am the smile

interpretation: The way dejected people, for the sake of their companions, would even smile-- that smile will be artificial. It will look like a smile/laugh, but it will be the same as a thousand tear-sheddings. (61)

māñgā

engTranslation:
1) the sleepy/drowsy road was insolent/'neck-lifting' 
      from a single lesson of awareness

      2) to the ground, my footstep 
      is the slap of an Ustad
notes:
dars : 'Reading, learning to read; a lecture; 
    a lesson, exercise'. (Platts p.512)
interpretation: This verse is about a situation in which the poet sees something, and says something. If the verse's superficial meaning is considered, then those roads that were unfamiliar with a human footstep, and that up till now had not taken the 'lesson of awareness' (they were 'sleepy')-- my footstep struck them and awakened them (the way a teacher slaps a pupil when he forgets a lesson).
sherText:
rah-e ḳhvābīdah thī gardan-kash-e yak-dars-e 
      āgāhī

      zamīñ ko sailī-e ustād hai naqsh-e qadam merā

engTranslation:
1a) don't call us ignorant/unaware, oh cruel one-- ask 
      (through)  self-regardingness!

      1b) don't call us cruel, oh ignorant/unaware one-- ask (through)  self-regardingness!

      

      2) in the ocean of the relish of/for sight, the mirror was {fordable / a ford}
notes:
pā-yāb : 'Within (one's) depth, fordable; --a ford'. 
    (Platts p.213)
interpretation: That is: oh cruel one, you call us ignorant of the springtime of beauty-- although when you were absorbed in self-adornment, at that time where was your mirror?! Now just listen: this mirror was drowned in my own relish of/for sight! That is, it was my own relish of/for spectacle that made you aware of your own beauty and absorbed in mirror-regarding. For pā-yāb is the opposite of drowning, but here Mirza has taken it in a contrary meaning. (43)
sherText:
be-ḳhabar mat kah hameñ be-dard ḳhvud-bīnī 
      se pūchh

      qulzum-e żauq-e naz̤ar meñ āʾinah pā-yāb thā

firstVerse:
shauq hai sāmāñ-t̤arāz-e nāzish-e 
      arbāb-e ʿajz

      żarrah ṣaḥrā-dast-gāh-o-qat̤rah daryā-āshnā
engTranslation:
1) ardor is the equipment-adorner of the glory/boasting/coquetry 
      of the lords/possessors of weakness

      2) the sand-grain is a desert-{power/knowledge/'hand-place'} and the 
      drop is a sea-{friend/swimmer}
interpretation:
He says, the property of the lords of weakness-- that is, 
    humans who are made of dust-- is the coquetry of passion, by reason of which 
    a nothing of a sand-grain becomes the desert and an insubstantial drop becomes 
    the sea. The meaning is that humans who are made of dust and have an insubstantial 
    existence, make such progress that... they obtain access to the Exalted Divine 
    Court, thanks to passion. (78)
sherText:
shauq hai sāmāñ-t̤arāz-e nāzish-e 
      arbāb-e ʿajz

      żarrah ṣaḥrā-dast-gāh-o-qat̤rah daryā-āshnā

firstVerse:
maiñ ʿadam se bhī pare hūñ 
      varnah ġhāfil bār-hā
secondVerse: merī āh-e ātishīñ se bāl-e ʿanqā jal gayā
engTranslation:
1a) I am beyond even/also nonexistence-- otherwise, 
      heedlessly, more than once

      1b) I am beyond even/also nonexistence-- otherwise, oh heedless one, more 
      than once
interpretation:
Anqa is the name of a nonexistent bird. And when he [=the speaker] became 
    nonexistent, he too was in nonexistence, and the fiery sighs and the wing 
    of the Anqa could come together in the same field. For this reason the wing 
    of the Anqa burned from his sighs. But the poet's saying 'I am outside even 
    nonexistence'-- the result of this is that I neither exist nor do not exist, 
    and I transcend opposites.
sherText:
maiñ ʿadam se bhī pare hūñ 
      varnah ġhāfil bār-hā

      merī āh-e ātishīñ se bāl-e ʿanqā jal gayā

interpretation: He has imagined madness as a world of madness, and in that capacity has called it a workshop where madmen are steadily created and sent forth. Then he has reflected that at the time when the madmen are created, it's necessary that their clothing would be removed; for this reason there must be heaps of torn-up garment-hems and collars lying around. But this idea was incorrect. After experience, he says that he went into a workshop where there ought to be no shortage of garment-hems and collars-- but look at the ill-fortune, that even there he obtained not even a single torn collar! ....
sherText:
kār-ḳhāne se junūñ ke bhī maiñ ʿuryāñ 
      niklā

      merī qismat kā nah ek-ādh garebāñ niklā

firstVerse: yak żarrah-e zamīñ nahīñ bekār bāġh kā

kā
engTranslation:
1) not a single grain of the earth of the garden is

      2) here even/also the path is the wick/bandage of the tulip's wound/brand
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {33}
sherText:

firstVerse:
shoḳhī-e rang-e ḥinā ḳhūn-e 
      vafā se kab tak

      āḳhir ay ʿahd-shikan tū bhī pashemāñ niklā
engTranslation:
1) the mischievousness of the color of henna, from 
      the blood/murder of faithfulness-- how long?

      2) finally, oh promise-breaker, even/also you turned out to be penitent/regretful
interpretation: That is, by continually applying henna to your hands, you did mischievousnesses toward the blood of faithfulness. But finally the color of faithfulness appeared clearly, and you were compelled to repent. He has said not that 'you did mischievousness'; rather, he's said that 'the color of henna did mischievousness'. This is a courteous/respectful introduction. (36)
sherText:
shoḳhī-e rang-e ḥinā ḳhūn-e 
      vafā se kab tak

      āḳhir ay ʿahd-shikan tū bhī pashemāñ niklā

      shauq dekhā chāhiye

      sīnah-e shamshīr se bāhar hai dam shamshīr kā
engTranslation:
1) the uncontrolled/uncontrollable passion/emotion 
      of ardor ought to be seen!

      2) the breath/life/edge of the sword is outside the sword's breast
notes: shamshīr : 'A sword, a scimitar'. (Platts p.733)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {1}
sherText:

      shauq dekhā chāhiye

      sīnah-e shamshīr se bāhar hai dam shamshīr kā

firstVerse:
dil se havā-e kisht-e vafā miṭ 
      gaʾī kih vāñ

      ḥāṣil sivā-e ḥasrat-e ḥāṣil nahīñ rahā
engTranslation:
1) from the heart the desire for the cultivation/tillage 
      of faithfulness was erased, since there

      2) outcome/produce, besides/beyond the longing/grief/regret for/of outcome/produce, 
      did not remain
interpretation:
He says, 'Now even the longing for the garden of faithfulness 
    has been erased from the heart. Enthusiasm has waned. Courage has taken its 
    leave, and the reason is that after faithfulness, I didn't find the tillage 
    of faithfulness to be anything but longing and regret.' (77)
sherText:
dil se havā-e kisht-e vafā miṭ 
      gaʾī kih vāñ

      ḥāṣil sivā-e ḥasrat-e ḥāṣil nahīñ rahā

engTranslation:
1) last night, when/since from the {taste for / relish of} your conversation, the heart was restless

      2) through the mischievousness of wildness/madness, the 'incantation of sleep' was a story
notes: fusūn : '(prob. akin to afsānah ) Enchantment, incantation, fascination, &c.'. (Platts p.781)
interpretation: That is, last night when the heart became restless to hear your conversation, and wildness began its mischievousnesses, then even/also the incantation of sleep became a story (that is, sleep vanished). Between afsānah and fusūn there's the device of [a shared] 'derivation' [ishtiqāq]. In the first line with an extremely displeasing knottiness [taʿqīd] he has said ;zauq se tere instead of tere żauq ; but there was the duress of the meter. (41)
sherText:
shab kih żauq-e guft-gū se terī dil be-tāb thā

      shoḳhī-e vaḥshat se afsānah fusūn-e ḳhvāb thā

secondVerse:
ham ne vaḥshat-kadah-e 
      bazm-e jahāñ meñ jūñ shamʿa

      shulah-e ʿishq ko apnā sar-o-sāmāñ samjhā
engTranslation:
1) we, in the desolation-chamber of the 
      gathering of the world, like a candle

      2) considered the flame of passion to be our equipment/effects
notes:
sar-o-sāmāñ : 'Apparatus, necessaries, 
    requisites, effects, goods and chattels'. (Platts p.649)
interpretation:
What is the equipment of a candle? Only a flame. We too understood 
    it to be the equipment of our life in the desolation-filled gathering of the 
    world, to keep burning with the flame of passion. Besides this, we had nothing, 
    nor did we need anything. Although finally this flame will extinguish our 
    very self, the way the flame of a candle devours the candle.
sherText:
ham ne vaḥshat-kadah-e 
      bazm-e jahāñ meñ jūñ shamʿa

      shulah-e ʿishq ko apnā sar-o-sāmāñ samjhā

firstVerse:

      mat pūchh
secondVerse:
is qadar tang huʾā dil kih maiñ
zindāñ samjhā
engTranslation:
1) don't ask for a commentary/'opening out' of 
      the reasons for confinement/bondage of temperament

      2) to such an extent the heart became narrow/oppressed that I considered 
      it a prison-cell
notes:
giriftārī : 'Seizure, capture, arrest, 
    apprehension; --captivity, imprisonment, bondage; embarrassment, entanglement'. 
    (Platts p.904)
interpretation:
sharḥ
has the meaning of 'opening', so it has an affinity with
'confinement' and 'narrow' and 'cell'. 'Don't ask me for a detailed
account of the reasons for the bondage of my heart'-- that is to say,
neither can I express it, nor can you listen to it.  (80)
sherText:
sharḥ-e asbāb-e giriftārī-e ḳhāt̤ir

zindāñ samjhā

engTranslation:
1) how can I say/speak a description of the relief/freedom

      2a) {whereas / since / although} I ate the heart's blood, I/it was without

      2b) whatever I ate, it was heart's blood without indebtedness to chyme

firstVerse:
hai kahāñ
              tamannā kā dūsrā qadam yā rab
secondVerse:
ham ne dasht-e imkāñ ko ek naqsh-e pā
              pāyā
engTranslation:
1) where is the second step of longing,
          oh Lord?

          2) we found the desert of possibility [to be] a
          single/particular/unique/excellent footprint
notes:
imkāñ : 'Possibility,
        practicability; power; contingent existence (in contrast to vujūb or necessary existence)'. (Platts
        p.82)
interpretation: It seems that Longing had come here, and had passed through this jungle/wilderness. But, oh my Lord, where did the second footstep of Longing fall? Because this desert of possibilities is a single footprint (he has given for the desert of possibilities the simile of a footprint). That is, this world is not a place for Longing to settle in. Longing grew anxious at the situation here and passed through so quickly that a single one of its footsteps fell here, which is in the form of the desert of possibilities. There's no knowing about the second footstep. (53)
sherText:
hai kahāñ
              tamannā kā dūsrā qadam yā rab

            ham ne dasht-e imkāñ ko ek naqsh-e pā
              pāyā

huʾā
secondVerse: mujh pah goyā ik zamānah mihr-bāñ ho jāʾegā
engTranslation:
1) in everyone's heart is your place; if you would become 
      favorable

      2) to me, so to speak, a single/particular/unique/excellent age/world will 
      become gracious/propitious
interpretation:
He's composed an extraordinarily eloquent [balīġh] 
    verse. (52)
sherText:
sab ke dil meñ hai jagah terī jo tū rāẓī
huʾā

      mujh pah goyā ik zamānah mihr-bāñ ho jāʾegā

engTranslation:
1) bloomingness is the ambush-place of {nearness/access/causation}-searching

      2) I am the image/vision/idea of the causelessly afflicted 
      ones
notes:
taṣavvur : 'Imaging or picturing (a thing) 
    to the mind; imagination, fancy; reflection, contemplation, meditation; forming 
    an idea; idea, conception, perception, apprehension'. (Platts p.326)
interpretation: That is, the way that the imaginations of  causelessly afflicted ones always search for some aspect of sorrow, since other than sorrow nothing else gives comfort to them, my situation is just the same. So that when an aspect of bloomingness would come before me, the heart would bring before the gaze dozens of kinds of witheredness, as if that happiness was a preface to sorrow.

firstVerse:
naqsh faryādī hai kis kī shoḳhī-e
              taḥrīr
              kā
secondVerse:
kāġhażī hai pairahan har paikar-e
              taṣvīr kā
engTranslation:
1) the drawing/picture is a plaintiff--
          about whose mischievousness of writing?

          2) of paper is the robe of every figure of/in the picture
notes:
naqsh : 'A painting, a
        picture; portrait; drawing; a print; a carving, an engraving; a
        map, or plan'. (Platts p.1145)
interpretation:
[1865, to Shakir:] First listen to the meaning of the
        meaningless verses. As for naqsh faryādī :
        In Iran there is the custom that the seeker of justice [dād-ḳhvāh], putting on paper garments,
        goes before the ruler-- as in the case of lighting a torch in
        the day, or carrying a blood-soaked cloth on a bamboo pole [to
        protest an injustice]. Thus the poet reflects, of whose
        mischievousness of writing is the image a plaintiff? --since the
        aspect of a picture is that its garment is of paper. That is to
        say, although existence may be like that of pictures, merely
        notional [ětibār-e maḥaẓ], it is a
        cause of grief and sorrow and suffering.
sherText:
naqsh faryādī hai kis kī shoḳhī-e
              taḥrīr
              kā

            kāġhażī hai pairahan har paikar-e
              taṣvīr kā

engTranslation:
1) only/emphatically you are not intimate with voices/sounds 
      of the secret/mystery

      2) otherwise, that which here is a curtain/veil, is the veil/tone 
      of a [musical] instrument/concord
interpretation:
That is, the thing that you consider a veil of the world 
    of divine reality [ḥaqīqat], it is the string of a 
    rabab [rabāb], from which melodies of the mystery of 
    divine reality arise. But it's you who cannot experience the pleasure of its 
    rhythm and tone. (13)

engTranslation:
1) intellect is enchained by the disconnectedness 
      of the heart, oh Lord

      2) in which language is my nickname 'disturbed dream'?
interpretation:
Understanding, because of my disconnected imaginings, has 
    become an enchained prisoner. That is, I think such disconnected things that 
    my comprehension itself doesn't manage to understand them; it has ended up 
    paralyzed and afflicted. People have given me the nickname 'disturbed dream', 
    but in which language have they given it? 'To some extent 'disturbed dream' 
    can be understood; my words absolutely can't be understood at all. I seem 
    to be the 'disturbed dream' of some mysterious language.

notes:

interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {48}

engTranslation:
1) where the world was presenting the 
      spread/carpet of existence

      2) like dawn, the tearing/fissure of the collar was to me a warp and woof
interpretation: He says that when in the bazaar of creation the shop of the goods of existence was opened, then in it the fabric of my existence had as its warp and woof only the tearing of a collar-- exactly the way the garment of the dawn has become only the tearing of a collar. (For the tearing of the collar of the dawn they use the metaphor of the tearing of the woof, because the light of dawn first appears in a single line.... The idea is that tearing my collar and being a madman in passion had been written in my destiny since the eternity before time. (28)

naqsh faryādī hai kis kī shoḳhī-e
              taḥrīr
              kā
secondVerse:
kāġhażī hai pairahan har paikar-e
              taṣvīr kā
engTranslation:
1) the drawing/picture is a plaintiff--
          about whose mischievousness of writing?

          2) of paper is the robe of every figure of/in the picture
interpretation:
[1865, to Shakir:] First listen to the meaning of the
        meaningless verses. As for naqsh faryādī :
        In Iran there is the custom that the seeker of justice [dād-ḳhvāh], putting on paper garments,
        goes before the ruler-- as in the case of lighting a torch in
        the day, or carrying a blood-soaked cloth on a bamboo pole [to
        protest an injustice]. Thus the poet reflects, of whose
        mischievousness of writing is the image a plaintiff? --since the
        aspect of a picture is that its garment is of paper. That is to
        say, although existence may be like that of pictures, merely
        notional [ětibār-e maḥaẓ], it is a
        cause of grief and sorrow and suffering.

engTranslation:
1) grace/favor/success is according to spirit/courage/ambition, 
      from origin/source/eternity

      2) in the eyes is that drop that had not become a pearl
interpretation:
That is, even if a teardrop becomes a pearl, how would it 
    obtain such honor, as if its place is in the eyes. The courage of the pearl-drop 
    was less than that of the teardrop. For this reason, it can reach as far as 
    the ears [in earrings], not as far as the eyes. (37)

secondVerse:
kuchh ḳhayāl āyā thā vaḥshat
kā kih ṣaḥrā jal gayā
engTranslation:
1a) how would the heat/fervor of the temper of thought/anxiety 
      be conveyed/expressed?

      1b) where would the heat/fervor of the temper of thought/anxiety be conveyed/displayed?

      1c) as if the heat/fervor of the temper of thought/anxiety would be conveyed/expressed!
interpretation:
He says, where might I go to utter the heat of my turbulent 
    themes? I had thought that 
    I could leave the city and utter it in the jungle. The moment a thought of 
    madness occurred, fire burst out in the jungle. Mirza Sahib's goal in this 
    utterance is: seeing the numerousness of those without understanding, it's 
    as if my inner self wants to write melting verse, but cannot do so, and cannot 
    see the fullest possible extent of the high-flyingnesses 
    of its thought. That is, I hesitate to express accomplishment before those 
    without understanding. (15)
sherText:

kahāñ

kā kih ṣaḥrā jal gayā

engTranslation:
1) you didn't kill [me], considering [me] guiltless, {heedlessly / heedless one},
on your neck

2) remained, like the blood of an innocent, the
right/claim of friendship
interpretation:
He blames her: the claim of friendship was that you should 
    have killed me. You considered me innocent, and so turned aside from my murder. 
    But you didn't know that the right/claim of friendship is on your neck the way the 
    blood of an innocent would have been. (25)

engTranslation:
1a) from eye to heart is a 'whole-mirrorful' of lamp-display-- 
      who

      1b) from eye to heart is a single mirror-lamps [display]-- who

      

      2) on the privacy/seclusion of coquetry, imposed/'bound' the embellishment 
      of a gathering?
notes:
nāz : 'Blandishment, coquetry, playfulness, 
    amorous playfulness, feigned disdain; dalliance, toying; fondling, coaxing, 
    soothing or endearing expression; --pride, conceit, consequential airs, whims; 
    --softness, delicacy; elegance, gracefulness'. (Platts p.1114)
interpretation: That is, from the eye to the heart is a single mirror, in which a lamp-display is being seen, and the existence of the lamp-display is a proof of the adornment of a gathering. Then, he asks with surprise, 'Oh Lord, who is this who has bestowed on privacy/seclusion (the heart) the embellishment of a gathering?'. The reason for calling the heart a mirror is its clearness, and that in it there is a lamp-display through the reflection of the beauty of the beloved. The theme is one of mystical knowledge. (39)

engTranslation:
1) don't give the lament/complaint so much length, 
      Ghalib, write {an abstract / briefly}

      2) that 'I am a longing-measurer of the breadth/petition of the 
      tyrannies of separation'
notes:
ʿarẓ : 'Presenting or representing; 
    representation, petition, request, address; --(v.n. fr. 'to be broad'), s.m. 
    Breadth, width; (in Geog.) latitude; --a military muster, a review'. (Platts 
    p.760)
interpretation:
He says, 'Oh Ghalib, when you lengthen the letter by writing 
    all kinds of laments and all types of complaints, what's the point? Write 
    a shortish sentence, that I have in my heart a longing to express the tyrannies 
    of separation and the suffering of being apart.' (51)

2) in the destiny/'cutting out' of which would be, to be a

interpretation:
That is, if there's separation, then he himself

firstVerse:
rāt din gardish meñ haiñ sāt āsmāñ

      ho rahegā kuchh nah kuchh ghabrāʾeñ kyā
engTranslation:
1) night and day they're in [a state of] revolving/turning/wandering, 
      the seven heavens

      2) something or other will end up happening-- why would/should we be perturbed/agitated?
notes:
ghabrānā : 'To be confused, confounded, 
    flurried, or flustered (by, or in consequence of, -se); to be perplexed, bewildered, 
    or embarrassed (by); to be perturbed, disturbed in mind, agitated, disquieted, 
    distracted; to be alarmed, scared, dismayed'. (Platts p.930)
interpretation:
[c.1859, to Mirza Rahim Beg:] I've already said that I have no relish for spectacles, 
    nor any respite from a host of physical ills and spiritual griefs. If formerly 
    I had a courage that had not been defeated, and a hope for help from the Unseen, 
    now this Urdu verse of mine is constantly on the tip of my tongue, and with 
    this habit I constantly give voice to my sighs: {46,2}.
sherText:
rāt din gardish meñ haiñ sāt āsmāñ

      ho rahegā kuchh nah kuchh ghabrāʾeñ kyā

engTranslation:
1) there, there was a crowd/rush of melodies of the [musical] instrument of conviviality, Asad

      2) the fingernail of grief, here, on the thread/string of the breath, was a plectrum
notes: ʿishrat : 'Social or familiar intercourse, pleasant and familiar conversation, society; pleasure, enjoyment, mirth'. (Platts p.761)
interpretation: That is, there, a gathering of music and pleasure was lively; and here, the fingernail of grief was picking/plucking the thread/string of our breath. (42)

    about; moving or springing from side to side... moving round ... coursing; ... 
    Fetters, irons'. (Platts p.398)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {23}
sherText:
asad ham vuh junūñ-jaulāñ gadā-e 
      be-sar-o-pā haiñ

      kih hai sar-panjah-e mizhgān-e āhū
pusht-ḳhār apnā

engTranslation:
1) the longing/sorrow of the intoxication of wildness/madness 
      is not according to the effort of the heart

      

      2a) the petition/breadth of the stretch/yawn of Majnun, 
      is my collar

      2b) my collar is the petition/breadth of the stretch/yawn of Majnun
interpretation:
In reality, in the first line the word 'longing' is only 
    padding, and is a cause of the destruction of meaning. A ḳhamyāzah 
    is a stretch/yawn [angaṛāʾī] that is a sign of the 
    decline or lack of intoxication.... He says that to me the intoxication of 
    wildness/madness is not proportional to my effort and desire. In my madness 
    when I have torn my collar, it is in reality the stretch/yawn of Majnun, that 
    symbolically speaking was the sign of the lack of the intoxication of madness. 
    I too, through the tearing of the collar, make manifest [my desire] that there 
    might be able to be a further increase in madness.
sherText:
ḥasrat-e nashshah-e vaḥshat nah bah saʿī-e 
      dil hai

      ʿarẓ-e ḳhamyāzah-e majnūñ hai garebāñ merā

firstVerse:
mashhad-e ʿāshiq se kosoñ tak jo 
      ugtī hai ḥinā

      kis qadar yā rab halāk-e ḥasrat-e pā-būs thā
engTranslation:
1) from the tomb of the lover, for miles, {the way 
      / in that / since} henna grows--

      

      2a) to what an extent, oh Lord, 
      there was killing/destruction of/by the longing for foot-kissing!

      2b) to what extent, oh Lord, 
      was there killing/destruction of/by the longing for foot-kissing?
notes:
halāk : 'Perishing; being lost; --perdition, 
    destruction, ruin; --slaughter; death'. (Platts p.1231)
interpretation:
Mirza Sahib says, in the lover's place of martyrdom, for 
    miles henna trees grow up. This is the effect of the blood that was shed at 
    the time of the killing. And the growth of henna is telling us to what extent 
    the martyr longed to kiss her feet. In life, he didn't have access to the 
    beloved's feet, but after becoming dust, now he's manifested himself in the 
    guise of henna and shown the longing to kiss her feet. If the beloved puts 
    henna on her feet, then this longing will be fulfilled. (75)
sherText:
mashhad-e ʿāshiq se kosoñ tak jo 
      ugtī hai ḥinā

      kis qadar yā rab halāk-e ḥasrat-e pā-būs thā

firstVerse: jamʿa karte ho kyūñ raqīboñ ko
secondVerse: ik tamāshā huʾā gilā nah huʾā

      2) a single/particular/unique/excellent spectacle occurred, a complaint/reproach 
      did not occur
notes:
ek : 'One, single, sole, alone, only, 
    a, an; the same, identical; only one; a certain one; single of its kind, unique, 
    singular, preëminent, excellent'. (Platts p.113)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {26}
sherText:
jamʿa karte ho kyūñ raqīboñ ko

      2) a spring raincloud-- the {cask/distillery}-house of whose mind?

ḳhum : 'A large vessel or jar; an alembic, 
    a still'. (Platts p.493)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {33}

engTranslation:
1a) she left off tyranny-- but would she leave off?

      1b) she left off tyranny, but-- as if she would leave off!
notes: jaur : 'Wrong-doing, injustice, oppression, violence, tyranny'. (Platts p.396)
interpretation:
That is, now out of shame she doesn't show her face; this 
    too is tyranny to me. (42)

jaur se bāz āʾe par bāz āʾeñ 
      kyā

engTranslation:
1) those withdrawal-choosing from the gathering are the 
      sight-exhausted ones 

      2) the glass of wine is the blister on the foot of the gaze
interpretation: In this verse, beyond affinity of words there's very little meaning! If the meaning would be pulled out, then it is that those people who are seated in a corner of the gathering are far from joining in; they  avoid the  beauty of the Cupbearer, or are even/also deprived of the sight of the 'daughter of the vine' [=wine]. Because the bottle [botal] of wine has become a blister on the foot of the gaze, and is an obstruction between them and the Cupbearer of the 'daughter of the vine'. (64)

secondVerse: maiñ nah achchhā huʾā burā nah huʾā
engTranslation:
1) pain did not become indebted to medicine

      2) I didn't become well/good; it wasn't ill/bad
notes: achchhā honā : 'To become or get well, to recover; to be healed or cured; to be in good health'. (Platts p.27)
interpretation:
This is not that 'good' that is the opposite of 'bad';
rather, 'to become good/well' means the abating of a disease. (27)

ġhālib
secondVerse:

sāḥil bāñdhā
engTranslation:
1) the themes 
      of the thirst of ardor did not become versified/'bound', Ghalib

      2) although [I/we/they] {unrestrainedly / 'having opened the heart'} versified/'bound' 
      even/also the sea as a 'shore'
notes: maẓmūn : 'That which is included or comprised (in a thing); the contents (of a writing or letter), what is implied (in a writing, &c.), import, sense, signification, meaning, tenour; —subject-matter, subject'. (Platts p.1043)
interpretation:
The themes of the relish of poetry, oh Ghalib, could not 
    be versified/'bound' the way we wanted to versify them, although we unrestrainedly 
    versified the sea as a shore. All the poets have constantly called the shore 
    thirsty. Although it keeps the sea in its embrace, nevertheless it looks dry-lipped. 
    To do some task 'with open heart' they call 'to use exaggeration in the task'. 
    (59-60)
sherText:
nah bañdhe tishnagī-e shauq ke maẓmūñ
ġhālib

engTranslation:
1) if I would call her 'Yusuf' 
      and she would say nothing-- wellbeing occurred!

      2) if she would insist on quarreling, then I was even/also worthy of punishment
notes: taʿzīr : 'Punishment, correction, reproof, censure, reprimand'. (Platts p.327)
interpretation:
He says, I called her Yusuf (that is, made her into a slave); 
    it was very fortunate that, hearing this praise from me, she fell silent. 
    If she had become angry, then I deserved punishment for calling her Yusuf. 
    (71)

engTranslation:
1) the mischievousness of the color of henna, from 
      the blood/murder of faithfulness-- how long?

      2) finally, oh promise-breaker, even/also you turned out to be penitent/regretful
notes:
pashemāñ : 'Penitent, sorry, repentant, 
    remorseful, filled with regret; abashed, ashamed; disgraced'. (Platts p.264)
interpretation: That is, by continually applying henna to your hands, you did mischievousnesses toward the blood of faithfulness. But finally the color of faithfulness appeared clearly, and you were compelled to repent. He has said not that 'you did mischievousness'; rather, he's said that 'the color of henna did mischievousness'. This is a courteous/respectful introduction. (36)

      2) the page of the mirror did not become the movement-place of a parrot
interpretation: I don't understand the 'amazement of the down'. It's possible that Mirza might have [made an error], or it might be an error of the copyist....

secondVerse: yih kāfir fitnah-e t̤āqat-rubā kyā
engTranslation:
1a) murderer, why this fortitude-testing promise?!

      1b) why this murderous fortitude-testing promise?!
interpretation:
The meaning is, why is a fortitude-testing vow made
to me? And this theme
of the first line is rearranged in different words in the second line. The
construction of the words is worthy of praise. (46)

      2a) the straw-mat was a whole reed-thicket-world [of] loud/lofty noise

naġhmah : 'A soft, sweet voice; --a musical

The meaning of be-navāʾī is lack 
    of possessions; that is, poverty. The meaning of navā

    ʿajam , the word be-navāʾī means not only 'poverty' 
    but also 'voicelessness'. In this verse, 'poverty' is intended. 'Voicelessness' 
    is only by way of an īhām 
    ,

be-navāʾī tar ṣadā-e naġhmah-e shuhrat

interpretation: He says that to the measure of the cruelty/tyranny of the sky, to that same measure the cruelty/tyranny of the wink of the blue eye of the beloved tormented me.... He has brought in 'azure eye' in order to create the same color as the sky. Otherwise, an 'azure eye' is not part of the Eastern vision of beauty. (30)

In the same way, when he heard this verse of Momin

pūchh mat rusvāʾī-e andāz-e istiġhnā-e

notes:
gashtah : 'Returned; turned; inverted, 
    reversed; converted; perverted; changed; --become; formed'. (Platts p.910)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {10}

ārzūʾeñ haiñ
chirāġh-e murdah hūñ
maiñ be-zabāñ gor-e ġharībāñ kā

firstVerse:
kyūñ nah vaḥshat-e ġhālib bāj-ḳhvāh-e 
      taskīñ ho

      kushtah-e taġhāful ko ḳhaṣm-e ḳhūñ-bahā pāyā
engTranslation:
1a) why wouldn't Ghalib's wildness/madness 
      be a {tax/toll}-receiver of peace/tranquility?

      1b) why wouldn't an overpowering wildness/madness be a  {tax/toll}-receiver of peace/tranquility?



      2) [they] found the one slain by negligence/heedlessness [to be] an 
      enemy of the 'blood-price'
interpretation: The one who has been slain by negligence will remain  subject only to neglect; what does he have to do with a blood-price? Ghalib too is slain by negligence-- his wildness/madness receives taxes from peace/tranquility. That is, the rank of his wildness/madness is higher than that of peace/tranquility. The idea is that Ghalib is not among those madmen who would be 'clever about their own affairs' [bah kār-e ḳhvesh hushyār]. Rather, his madness is the result of a disconnection from property, that would be a cause of inner peace.
sherText:
kyūñ nah vaḥshat-e ġhālib bāj-ḳhvāh-e 
      taskīñ ho

      kushtah-e taġhāful ko ḳhaṣm-e ḳhūñ-bahā pāyā

engTranslation:
1) Hopelessness, in approaching/recommendng themes 
      of intoxication/hangover

      2) versified/'bound' the 'lane of the wave' as 'the stretch/yawn of 
      the shore'
notes:
ḳhamyāzah : 'Stretching; yawning, gaping'. 
    (Platts p.494)
interpretation: Because a wave is long and has turn after turn, it is given the simile of a lane. Here, what is meant is a 'wave of wine' [mauj-e sharāb]. ḳhamyāzah = yawn, it is used as a metaphor for the stretch of the shore; a wave too has a similitude with a yawn, and  ḳhumār necessarily has a yawn. The meaning is that there was hopelessness about obtaining wine, and the   ḳhumār had gone beyond the limit; thus when he sat down to write the theme of ḳhumār , then in the preface he wrote down the 'lane of the wave' as the 'shore'. That is, although in the gathering of the Cupbearer an ocean of wine was rippling, the cup of my destiny seemed to me to be empty.
sherText:
nā-umīdī ne bah taqrīb-e maẓāmīn-e 
      ḳhumār

      kūchah-e mauj ko ḳhamyāzah-e sāḥil bāñdhā

firstVerse:
qaid meñ hai tire vaḥshī ko vuhī 
      zulf kī yād

      hāñ kuchh-ik ranj-e girāñ-bārī-e zanjīr bhī thā
engTranslation:
1) in shackles/bondage, your wild one has that same memory of curls

      2) indeed/yes, there was even/also some small trouble/pain/vexation 
      of the heaviness of the chains
interpretation:
He says, your madman has still not forgotten your curls, 
    by which he had previously been imprisoned. Although along with it, he also 
    had a light thought of the heaviness of the chains also. Through this mention, 
    he wanted to show that the imprisonment in chains is less in harshness than 
    the imprisonment of the curls. (70)
sherText:
qaid meñ hai tire vaḥshī ko vuhī 
      zulf kī yād

      hāñ kuchh-ik ranj-e girāñ-bārī-e zanjīr bhī thā

      2) the secret/mystery of the letter, she understood from the disconnectedness

notes: unvān : 'Superscription, title, or title-page (of a book, &c.); preface; anything that serves as an indication (of another thing); that which is understood (by anything); —mode, manner'. (Platts p.766)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {34}
sherText:
vuh mirī chīn-e jabīñ se ġham-e pinhāñ
samjhā

kā
engTranslation:
1) not a single grain of the earth of the garden is 
      useless

      2) here even/also the path is the wick/bandage of the tulip's wound/brand
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {33}
sherText:
yak żarrah-e zamīñ nahīñ bekār bāġh kā
yāñ jādah bhī fatīlah hai lāle ke dāġh
kā

engTranslation:
1) bloomingness is the ambush-place of {nearness/access/causation}-searching

      2) I am the image/vision/idea of the causelessly afflicted 
      ones
notes:
āzurdah : 'Afflicted ... sad, dispirited, 
    sorrowful; vexed... displeased, dissatisfied; weary'. (Platts p.45)
interpretation: That is, the way that the imaginations of  causelessly afflicted ones always search for some aspect of sorrow, since other than sorrow nothing else gives comfort to them, my situation is just the same. So that when an aspect of bloomingness would come before me, the heart would bring before the gaze dozens of kinds of witheredness, as if that happiness was a preface to sorrow.
sherText:
shiguftan kamīñ-gāh-e taqrīb-jūʾī

surmah-e muft-e

engTranslation:
1) I am free collyrium for the
          sight/gaze, my price/worth is this--

          2) that my kindness/favor/obligation would remain on the eyes
          of the purchaser
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {44}
sherText:

              naz̤ar hūñ mirī qīmat yih hai

              kih rahe chashm-e ḳharīdār pah iḥsāñ merā

firstVerse:
satāyish-gar hai zāhid is qadar jis bāġh-e riẓvāñ
kā
secondVerse:
vuh ik guldastah hai ham be-ḳhvudoñ ke t̤āq-e nisyāñ 
      kā
engTranslation:
1) that Garden of Rizvan of which the Ascetic is a praiser to such an extent--

      2) it is a single/particular/unique/excellent bouquet in the 'niche of forgetfulness' 
      of us self-less ones
notes:
t̤āq : 'An arched building; an arch; 
    a cupola, vault; a recess (in a wall), a niche; a shelf; ... —adj. & s.m. Single, sole; uneven, odd (opp. to juft ); singular, rare, unique, unmatched, unequalled, unrivalled'. (Platts p.750)
interpretation:
To 'put something in a niche', or put it 'at the top
of the niche', is an idiom for forgetting about it, and to put it 'in
the niche of forgetfulness' is even more of an exaggeration. And here
the word 'bouquet' has produced this beauty: that people put bouquets
in niches for decoration. And the second point is that the Garden has
been interpreted as a bouquet in a lowly place; this too is not devoid
of beauty. But this beauty is associated with style and rarity [badīʿ]; there is no excellence of meaning. (10)
sherText:
satāyish-gar hai zāhid is qadar jis bāġh-e riẓvāñ
kā

      vuh ik guldastah hai ham be-ḳhvudoñ ke t̤āq-e nisyāñ 
      kā

firstVerse:

      qufl-e abjad

      thā likhā bāt ke bante hī judā ho jānā
engTranslation:
1) with/from you, in my destiny, like/'with the aspect 
      of' a combination lock

      2) was written-- at only/emphatically the moment of   succeeding/'clicking', to become 
      separated
notes: bāt ban'nā : 'To be snccessful, prove  a success, answer well; to gain credit or honour, to  prosper, flourish'. (Platts p.117)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {48}
sherText:

firstVerse:
nah de nāle ko itnā t̤ūl ġhālib muḳhtaṣar likh
de
secondVerse:
kih ḥasrat-sanj hūñ ʿarẓ-e sitamhā-e
judāʾī kā
engTranslation:
1) don't give the lament/complaint so much length, 
      Ghalib, write {an abstract / briefly}

      2) that 'I am a longing-measurer of the breadth/petition of the 
      tyrannies of separation'
interpretation:
He says, 'Oh Ghalib, when you lengthen the letter by writing 
    all kinds of laments and all types of complaints, what's the point? Write 
    a shortish sentence, that I have in my heart a longing to express the tyrannies 
    of separation and the suffering of being apart.' (51)
sherText:
nah de nāle ko itnā t̤ūl ġhālib muḳhtaṣar likh
de
kih ḥasrat-sanj hūñ ʿarẓ-e sitamhā-e
judāʾī kā

firstVerse:
kyūñ nah vaḥshat-e ġhālib bāj-ḳhvāh-e 
      taskīñ ho

      kushtah-e taġhāful ko ḳhaṣm-e ḳhūñ-bahā pāyā
engTranslation:
1a) why wouldn't Ghalib's wildness/madness 
      be a {tax/toll}-receiver of peace/tranquility?

      1b) why wouldn't an overpowering wildness/madness be a  {tax/toll}-receiver of peace/tranquility?



      2) [they] found the one slain by negligence/heedlessness [to be] an 
      enemy of the 'blood-price'
interpretation: The one who has been slain by negligence will remain  subject only to neglect; what does he have to do with a blood-price? Ghalib too is slain by negligence-- his wildness/madness receives taxes from peace/tranquility. That is, the rank of his wildness/madness is higher than that of peace/tranquility. The idea is that Ghalib is not among those madmen who would be 'clever about their own affairs' [bah kār-e ḳhvesh hushyār]. Rather, his madness is the result of a disconnection from property, that would be a cause of inner peace.
sherText:
kyūñ nah vaḥshat-e ġhālib bāj-ḳhvāh-e 
      taskīñ ho

      kushtah-e taġhāful ko ḳhaṣm-e ḳhūñ-bahā pāyā

engTranslation:
1) {whose thought / the thought of whom} was a mirror 
      of waiting?

      2) in the veil/pardah of every rose-leaf, a heart was restless
notes:
pardah : 'A curtain, screen, cover, veil, 
    anything which acts as a screen, a wall, hangings, tapestry; ... secrecy, 
    privacy, modesty; seclusion, concealment; secret, mystery, reticence, reserve; 
    screen, shelter, pretext, pretence'. (Platts p.246)
interpretation: 'Whose' is a rhetorical question-- that is, the beloved's. He says that 'Memory of the beloved was mirroring my restless heart, in the state of waiting, in such a way that it had made every rose-leaf into a mirror'. The point is that the thought of the beloved so dominated me that with the sight of every single rose-leaf her memory became fresh, and my heart became restless. (57)
sherText:
kis kā ḳhayāl āʾinah-e intiz̤ār thā

      har barg-e gul ke parde meñ dil be-qarār thā

      2) the averting of the arrowhead of fate/death, it considered easy to that/(this)

secondVerse:

thā
engTranslation:
1) I was doing a compilation of the manuscripts/prescriptions/recipes of faithfulness

      

      2a) the collection of thoughts was still/now in bits and pieces

      2b) the sum/aggregate of my thought was still/now fragmentary
notes:
majmūʿah : 'The collective mass (of), 
    the whole (of), the aggregate (of); the sum (of); a crowd, an assembly; a 
    collection; meeting; a compendium; a body (of laws); a magazine; a miscellany; 
    --a form (in printing)'. (Platts p.1003)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {7}

      rahā thā maiñ

      majmūʿah-e ḳhayāl abhī fard fard
thā

engTranslation:
1) the agitation/palpitation of the mirror brought 
      the completion/perfection of longing

      

      2a) it tied the letter of ardor to a wing with wounded/slaughtered feathers

      2b) it composed/'bound' the letter of ardor with the wing/arm of a wounded/slaughtered 
      quill-pen
notes: pardāz : 'Performing, accomplishing, finishing, completing, ... ;--finish, accomplishment, perfection'. (Platts p.246)
interpretation:
For calling the mirror restless, there can be two reasons. 
    It has a brightness like that of mercury [which is used for the backing of 
    glass mirrors], and mercury is a prime example of restlessness. Or again, 
    in a metal mirror the polish-lines look as if they are writhing....

firstVerse:
qaid meñ hai tire vaḥshī ko vuhī 
      zulf kī yād

      hāñ kuchh-ik ranj-e girāñ-bārī-e zanjīr bhī thā
engTranslation:
1) in shackles/bondage, your wild one has that same memory of curls

      2) indeed/yes, there was even/also some small trouble/pain/vexation 
      of the heaviness of the chains
notes: kuchh-ek : 'Somewhat, some little, a little'. (Platts p.819)
interpretation:
He says, your madman has still not forgotten your curls, 
    by which he had previously been imprisoned. Although along with it, he also 
    had a light thought of the heaviness of the chains also. Through this mention, 
    he wanted to show that the imprisonment in chains is less in harshness than 
    the imprisonment of the curls. (70)
sherText:

firstVerse:
maḥram nahīñ hai tū hī navāhā-e rāz
kā
secondVerse:
yāñ varnah jo ḥijāb hai pardah hai
sāz kā
engTranslation:
1) only/emphatically you are not intimate with voices/sounds 
      of the secret/mystery

      2) otherwise, that which here is a curtain/veil, is the veil/tone 
      of a [musical] instrument/concord
interpretation:
That is, the thing that you consider a veil of the world 
    of divine reality [ḥaqīqat], it is the string of a 
    rabab [rabāb], from which melodies of the mystery of 
    divine reality arise. But it's you who cannot experience the pleasure of its 
    rhythm and tone. (13)
sherText:
maḥram nahīñ hai tū hī navāhā-e rāz
kā
yāñ varnah jo ḥijāb hai pardah hai
sāz kā

engTranslation:
1) the brick, a 'back of the hand' of weakness; and the mould/framework, an embrace of leave-taking

      2) it has become filled with the flood-- the measure/capacity of which construction?
notes: paimānah : 'A measure (for dry or wet goods); measure (of length, or capacity, &c.) ... ; a cup, bowl, goblet'. (Platts p.301)
interpretation: He says that in the tempest of the rainy season, falling bricks place the 'back of the hand' on the ground to express weakness, and in order to take leave of them an embrace has been spread. This is a preferred theme of Ghalib, which he has versified in various places in different guises. From this it seems that it is his real life story [āp-bītī ḥaqīqat hai]. (24)
sherText:
ḳhisht pusht-e dast-e ʿajz-o-qālib āġhosh-e vidāʿ

pur huʾā hai sail se paimānah kis taʿmīr kā

secondVerse: toṛā jo tū ne āʾinah timṡāl-dār thā
engTranslation:
1) now I am, and mourning of/for a 'cityful' of longing

      2) the mirror that you broke-- it was {likeness/image}-possessing
notes:
timṡāl : 'Resemblance, likeness, picture, 
    portrait, image, effigy'. (Platts p.336)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {16}
sherText:
ab maiñ hūñ aur mātam-e yak-shahr ārzū

      toṛā jo tū ne āʾinah timṡāl-dār thā

engTranslation:
1) oh you who have not made a habit/custom of control/restraint of your condition: the ebullience of madness

      2) is the intoxication of wine-- if it would be a 'single/whole veil' more refined/sensitive
notes: nāzuk : 'Thin, slender, slim, delicate, tender, fragile; fine; light; brittle; nice; neat; elegant; genteel; subtle; —facetious; gracious; keen; sensitive, touchy, testy'. (Platts p.1114)
interpretation: Oh, you who are not displeased with the control of the condition! [Zamin's text has ḥāl-e nā-afsurdagāñ .] That is, 'Oh people in whose hearts there has occurred no obstruction to control and suppression of the secret of passion'.
sherText:
ay bah ẓabt̤-e ḥāl ḳhū nā-kardagāñ josh-e junūñ

nashʾah-e mai hai agar yak-pardah nāzuk-tar huʾā

firstVerse:
zahrah gar aisā hī shām-e hijr meñ hotā hai
āb
secondVerse: partav-e mahtāb sail-e ḳhān-māñ ho jāʾegā
engTranslation:
1a) if during the evening of separation the gall-bladder 
      [habitually] is only/emphatically suc h water/luster

      1b) if during the evening of separation one is [habitually] terrified only/emphatically 
      in such a way

      

      2) [then] the ray of moonlight will become a flow/torrent of the household
interpretation:
He says, 'If this rule has been established that the harshnesses 
    of the evening of separation turn the gall-bladder into water, and cause it 
    to weep tears of blood, then it's not strange that moonlight would become 
    a flood of water and carry away the doors and walls of my house'. (52)
sherText:
zahrah gar aisā hī shām-e hijr meñ hotā hai
āb

      partav-e mahtāb sail-e ḳhān-māñ ho jāʾegā

secondVerse:
ham ne vaḥshat-kadah-e 
      bazm-e jahāñ meñ jūñ shamʿa

      shulah-e ʿishq ko apnā sar-o-sāmāñ samjhā
engTranslation:
1) we, in the desolation-chamber of the 
      gathering of the world, like a candle

      2) considered the flame of passion to be our equipment/effects
notes:
vaḥshat : 'A desert, solitude, dreary 
    place; --loneliness, solitariness, dreariness; --sadness, grief, care; --wildness, 
    fierceness, ferocity, savageness; barbarity, barbarism; --timidity, fear, 
    fright, dread, terror, horror; --distraction, madness'. (Platts p.1183)
interpretation:
What is the equipment of a candle? Only a flame. We too understood 
    it to be the equipment of our life in the desolation-filled gathering of the 
    world, to keep burning with the flame of passion. Besides this, we had nothing, 
    nor did we need anything. Although finally this flame will extinguish our 
    very self, the way the flame of a candle devours the candle.
sherText:
ham ne vaḥshat-kadah-e 
      bazm-e jahāñ meñ jūñ shamʿa

      shulah-e ʿishq ko apnā sar-o-sāmāñ samjhā

firstVerse:
ʿarẓ-e niyāz-e ʿishq ke qābil 
      nahīñ rahā

      jis dil pah nāz thā mujhe vuh dil nahīñ rahā
engTranslation:
1) [it/I] did not remain capable of the offering of 
      the submission of passion

      2) the heart on which I prided myself-- that heart did not remain
notes:
nāz : 'Pride, conceit, consequential 
    airs, whims'. (Platts p.1114)
interpretation:
That is, through enduring and enduring the shocks of faithlessness 
    and inattentiveness, now that heart itself no longer remains to me, with which 
    I would claim to offer the submission of love. (38)
sherText:
ʿarẓ-e niyāz-e ʿishq ke qābil 
      nahīñ rahā

      jis dil pah nāz thā mujhe vuh dil nahīñ rahā

firstVerse: dard minnat-kash-e davā nah huʾā
secondVerse: maiñ nah achchhā huʾā burā nah huʾā
engTranslation:
1) pain did not become indebted to medicine

      2) I didn't become well/good; it wasn't ill/bad
interpretation:
This is not that 'good' that is the opposite of 'bad';
rather, 'to become good/well' means the abating of a disease. (27)
sherText:
dard minnat-kash-e davā nah huʾā

maiñ nah achchhā huʾā burā nah huʾā

firstVerse:
żikr us parī-vash kā aur phir bayāñ 
      apnā

      ban gayā raqīb āḳhir thā jo rāz-dāñ apnā
engTranslation:
1) the mention/account of that Fairy-faced 
      one; and then-- my expression/description 

      2) he became a Rival finally-- 
      {he who / since he} was my confidant/'secret-knower'
interpretation:
That is, he too became a lover-- first, because the mention 
    itself is heart-alluring, and second, from the lips of a person who's becoming 
    infatuated. And then, this is 'magic of speech'. (40)
sherText:
żikr us parī-vash kā aur phir bayāñ 
      apnā

      ban gayā raqīb āḳhir thā jo rāz-dāñ apnā

firstVerse:
dost ġham-ḳhvārī meñ merī saʿī 
      farmāveñge kyā
secondVerse:
zaḳhm ke bharne talak nāḳhun nah baṛh
jāveñge kyā
engTranslation:
1a) what help, in {my affliction / sympathy with me}, 
      will friends attempt to bestow?

      1b) will friends attempt to bestow help, in {my affliction / sympathy with 
      me}?

      1c) as if friends will attempt to bestow help, in {my affliction / sympathy 
      with me}!
interpretation:
How excellently he has presented the meaning that my friends, 
    in sympathy-- what more can they do than having my nails cut? In the state 
    of madness, I keep scratching the wound and don't let it heal. After the nails 
    are cut, it's hoped that the wound will quickly heal. In opposition to my 
    friends, I'm thinking, by the time the wound heals, my cut nails too will 
    grow, and all their efforts will become useless in a single moment, because 
    I will again deepen the wound. (40)
sherText:
dost ġham-ḳhvārī meñ merī saʿī 
      farmāveñge kyā

      zaḳhm ke bharne talak nāḳhun nah baṛh
jāveñge kyā

      / 'bound on'} a litter

      2) the heat of ardor bound on to every sand-grain a single/particular/unique/excellent

interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {29}
sherText:

bāñdhā

ik dil bāñdhā

engTranslation:
1) in every color/mood/style Asad the
{affliction/discord/sedition}-awaiter burned 

2) he was a Moth
of the radiance/manifestation of the candle of appearance/manifestation
notes:
z̤uhūr : 'Appearing, arising,
springing up; appearance, manifestation, visibility; coming to pass'.
(Platts p.756)
interpretation:
Asad was a Moth of the Divine Light. Thus no matter
what the situation would be, he always burned.
sherText:
har rang meñ jalā asad-e
fitnah-intiz̤ār

parvānah-e tajallī-e shamʿ-e z̤uhūr thā

firstVerse:
rāt din gardish meñ haiñ sāt āsmāñ

      ho rahegā kuchh nah kuchh ghabrāʾeñ kyā
engTranslation:
1) night and day they're in [a state of] revolving/turning/wandering, 
      the seven heavens

      2) something or other will end up happening-- why would/should we be perturbed/agitated?
interpretation:
[c.1859, to Mirza Rahim Beg:] I've already said that I have no relish for spectacles, 
    nor any respite from a host of physical ills and spiritual griefs. If formerly 
    I had a courage that had not been defeated, and a hope for help from the Unseen, 
    now this Urdu verse of mine is constantly on the tip of my tongue, and with 
    this habit I constantly give voice to my sighs: {46,2}.
sherText:
rāt din gardish meñ haiñ sāt āsmāñ

      ho rahegā kuchh nah kuchh ghabrāʾeñ kyā

firstVerse:
lāg ho to us ko ham samjheñ lagāʾo

      jab nah ho kuchh bhī to dhokā khāʾeñ kyā
engTranslation:
1) if enmity/'laag' would exist, then we would consider it 
      affection

      

      2a) when nothing at all would exist, then-- as if we would be deceived!

      2b) when nothing at all would exist, then-- would we be deceived?
notes:
lagāʾo : 'Attachment, connexion; bond, 
    link; ...inclination, propensity'. (Platts p.961)
interpretation:
That is, even if she showed hatred, we would consider it 
    love. (42)
sherText:
lāg ho to us ko ham samjheñ lagāʾo

      jab nah ho kuchh bhī to dhokā khāʾeñ kyā

firstVerse: yih qātil vaʿdah-e ṣabr-āzmā kyūñ
secondVerse: yih kāfir fitnah-e t̤āqat-rubā kyā
engTranslation:
1a) murderer, why this fortitude-testing promise?!

      1b) why this murderous fortitude-testing promise?!
notes:
fitnah : 'Trial, affliction, calamity, 
    mischief, evil, torment, plague'. (Platts p.776)
interpretation:
The meaning is, why is a fortitude-testing vow made
to me? And this theme
of the first line is rearranged in different words in the second line. The
construction of the words is worthy of praise. (46)
sherText:
yih qātil vaʿdah-e ṣabr-āzmā kyūñ

yih kāfir fitnah-e t̤āqat-rubā kyā

ětibār-e ʿishq kī ḳhānah-ḳharābī

firstVerse:

      2) [his] heart, from the style of the warmth/fervor of the people of the 
      world, burned up
interpretation:
Oh Friendlessness, Asad is now not influenced by dejection. 
    He has seen the warmth and ebullience of the people of the world, and having 
    seen its artificialness and triviality his heart has burned. Now he has arrived 
    beyond the feeling of dejection. (110)

mirā shumūl 
      har ik dil ke pech-o-tab meñ hai

      maiñ muddaʿā hūñ tapish-nāmah-e tamannā kā
engTranslation:
1) my containment/inclusion is in the restlessness/vexation 
      of every single heart

      2) I am the claim/meaning/object of the agitation-letter of longing
interpretation:
If in this verse 
    there had been tirā shumūl and tu 
    muddaʿā hai , then the meaning would have become very clear. In the 
    present situation, it is presumably that I am embodied passion. Passion is 
    included in the writhing of every heart; thus I am a necessary part of the 
    writhing of every man's heart. When someone expresses the restlessness of 
    his longings in the form of a letter, then its essential, fundamental virtue/temper 
    will be myself alone, because I alone am the perfect example of the restlessness 
of the longing of passion.
sherText:

firstVerse:
jab tak kih nah dekhā thā qad-e 
      yār kā ʿālam

      maiñ muʿtaqid-e fitnah-e maḥshar nah huʾā thā
engTranslation:
1) as long as I had not seen the state/situation of 
      the height/stature of the beloved

      2) I had not become a believer/follower of the affliction/mischief of Judgment Day
interpretation:
The beloved's stature always receives the simile 
    of the affliction of Doomsday or the cypress and poplar in the garden. He 
    says, as long as I had not seen with my own eyes the style of the beloved's 
    stature, and the spectacle of her gait which is like Judgment Day, I was not 
    in my heart convinced of the affliction of Doomsday. (73)
sherText:
jab tak kih nah dekhā thā qad-e 
      yār kā ʿālam

      maiñ muʿtaqid-e fitnah-e maḥshar nah huʾā thā

engTranslation:
1a) the springtime of the color/style of the blood of the rose, is the equipment of tear-scattering 

      1b) the equipment of tear-scattering, is the springtime of the color/style of the rose



      2) the madness of the lightning, is the lancet of the vein of the springtime cloud
notes: sāmān : 'Furniture, baggage, articles, things, paraphernalia; requisites, necessaries, materials, appliances; instrument, tools, apparatus; provision made for any necessary occasion, necessary preparations'. (Platts p.627)
interpretation: He says, 'What is it for the spring season to come? It is the preface to tear-scattering. The clouds have closed in, the lightning has writhed and put a lancet into their vein (the 'vein of a cloud' is an overt metaphor), water has rained down, the flowers have bloomed (gardens and summer-houses have become colorful with the blood of the roses). In short, sorrowful hearts don't find pleasure even in the springtime. They consider the clouds' raining down to be weeping, and the flowers' blooming to be the flowing of the roses' blood.'
sherText:
bahār-e rang-e ḳhūn-e gul hai sāmāñ ashk-bārī kā

junūn-e barq nashtar hai rag-e abr-e bahārī kā

      2) in anger she/He has the manner of a ruler/commander
interpretation:
That is, when does the sky have this talent for
behaving like an idol? There's some Beloved behind the curtain of the
mirror's backing. (28)
