1) if delay occurred, then there was even/also some 
      cause of delay

      2) she herself {came / was on the way}-- but/perhaps there was even/also 
      some restrainer/'rein-puller'
notes: ʿinān : 'A rein; bridle'. (Platts 766)
interpretation:
He says, 'You came as you had promised, but you came late. 
    There must certainly have been some reason for this delay. Perhaps the reason 
    might be that the Other 
    stopped you from coming here.' (69-70)
sherText:
huʾī tāḳhīr to kuchh bāʿiṡ-e 
      tāḳhīr bhī thā 

      āp āte the magar koʾī ʿināñ-gīr bhī thā

firstVerse:
kiyā āʾīnah-ḳhāne kā vuh naqshah tere jalve
ne
secondVerse: kare jo partav-e ḳhvurshīd ʿālam shabnamistāñ kā
engTranslation:
1) your glory/appearance made of the mirror-chamber 
      that picture/aspect/state--

      2) the scene/aspect/state that a ray of the sun would make of a land of dew
notes:
naqshah : 'A delineation; a portrait; a picture; —a design; a  plan; a model, pattern, an exemplar; —a map, chart; —a  sketch, draught; ... —a prospect; state of  affairs or things; condition'. 
  (Platts p.1145)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {10}
sherText:
kiyā āʾīnah-ḳhāne kā vuh naqshah tere jalve
ne

      kare jo partav-e ḳhvurshīd ʿālam shabnamistāñ kā

engTranslation:
1) Hopelessness, in approaching/recommendng themes 
      of intoxication/hangover

      2) versified/'bound' the 'lane of the wave' as 'the stretch/yawn of 
      the shore'
interpretation: Because a wave is long and has turn after turn, it is given the simile of a lane. Here, what is meant is a 'wave of wine' [mauj-e sharāb]. ḳhamyāzah = yawn, it is used as a metaphor for the stretch of the shore; a wave too has a similitude with a yawn, and  ḳhumār necessarily has a yawn. The meaning is that there was hopelessness about obtaining wine, and the   ḳhumār had gone beyond the limit; thus when he sat down to write the theme of ḳhumār , then in the preface he wrote down the 'lane of the wave' as the 'shore'. That is, although in the gathering of the Cupbearer an ocean of wine was rippling, the cup of my destiny seemed to me to be empty.
sherText:
nā-umīdī ne bah taqrīb-e maẓāmīn-e 
      ḳhumār

      kūchah-e mauj ko ḳhamyāzah-e sāḥil bāñdhā

firstVerse:
go maiñ rahā rahīn-e sitamhā-e 
      rozgār

      lekin tire ḳhayāl se ġhāfil nahīñ rahā
interpretation:
He says, 'Despite the fact that I remained ensnared in the 
    grief and sorrow of the world, your memory never left my heart at any time 
    or in any situation, and I never neglected your memory'. This verse and the 
    previous one are in an especially Sufistic style. (77)
sherText:
go maiñ rahā rahīn-e sitamhā-e 
      rozgār

      lekin tire ḳhayāl se ġhāfil nahīñ rahā

firstVerse: vāʾe dīvānagī-e shauq kih har dam mujh ko
secondVerse: āp jānā udhar aur āp hī ḥairāñ honā
engTranslation:
1) alas, the madness of passion! --that at every moment/breath 
      I 

      2) myself have to go in that direction, and only/emphatically myself have to be astonished
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {17}
sherText:
vāʾe dīvānagī-e shauq kih har dam mujh ko
āp jānā udhar aur āp hī ḥairāñ honā

engTranslation:
1) {although / to such an extent / since} the illusion/suspicion 
      of the slaughtered one was turned-to-blood by the envy/jealousy of faithfulness

      2) the wounds of the heart stole/absorbed the 'water' of the murderer's/murderous 
      sword
notes:
vahm : 'Thinking, imagining, conceiving 
    (esp. a false idea); --opinion, conjecture; imagination, idea, fancy; --suspicion, 
    doubt; scruple, caution; distrust, anxiety, apprehension, fear'. (Platts p.1205)
interpretation: The wounded/slaughtered one's flood of tears deceives him into fearing that someone else might somehow drink the water of the murderer's sword. That is, that the murderer might with her 'water'-possessing sword murder someone else. Thus the wounds of his heart drink up all the 'water' of the sword, so that there would not be of it left. The result is that having wounded him, the murderer's sword became 'water'-less; there's an additional meaning of showing his 'tough-lifedness' [saḳht-jānī]. (59)
sherText:
z-bas ḳhūñ-gashtah-e rashk-e vafā thā 
      vahm bismil kā

      churāyā zaḳhm'hā-e dil ne pānī teġh-e qātil kā

firstVerse: muḥābā kyā hai maiñ ẓāmin idhar dekh
secondVerse: shahīdān-e nigah kā ḳhūñ-bahā kyā
engTranslation:
1) what concern/caution is there? I am responsible-- 
      look this way!
notes:
ḳhūñ-bahā : 'The price of blood, blood-money, 
    a fine for blood-shedding: -- ḳhūñ bahānā , To shed 
    blood'. (Platts p.497)
interpretation:
It is contrary to custom for a blood-price to be taken
for martyrs of a glance. So why are you afraid? Cast off fear and look
toward me; if I die, I take responsibility for it, no questions will be
asked of you. The excellence and supremacy with which Mirza Sahib has
presented this theme
is manifest.  (46)
sherText:
muḥābā kyā hai maiñ ẓāmin idhar dekh

shahīdān-e nigah kā ḳhūñ-bahā kyā

engTranslation:
1) {polish-line}-invention of
      the line of green [down], is the self-regarding of beauty

      2) what [we/he/it] had not seen, that {turned out to be / emerged from being} hidden in the 
      mirror
notes:
jauhar : 'A gem, jewel; a pearl; essence, 
    matter, substance, constituent, material part (opp. to accident), absolute 
    or essential property; skill, knowledge, accomplishment, art; excellence, 
    worth, merit, virtue; secret nature; defects, vices; --the diversified wavy 
    marks, streaks, or grain of a well-tempered sword; --adj. Bright, shining, 
    glittering'. (Platts p.399)
interpretation:
Those lines and marks that become apparent from the scraping/polishing 
    of a steel mirror are called the 'polish-lines' [jauhar] 
    of the mirror. Because in the rainy season the mirror is affected by something 
    like a greenish film, the 'polish-lines' too will become green, and in this 
    way, willy-nilly, the reflection of greenery will begin to show in the mirror.
sherText:
jauhar-ījād-e ḳhat̤-e sabz hai ḳhvud-bīnī-e 
      ḥusn

      jo nah dekhā thā so āʾīne meñ pinhāñ niklā

engTranslation:
1) I/we saw the faithfulness of the leisure for the 
      sorrow and joy of the age/time/world

      

      2a) a stretch/yawn was the whole length of a lifetime of  intoxication/hangover

      2b) the  whole length of a lifetime of intoxication/hangover was a stretch/yawn
notes:
dahr : 'Time; a long period of time; an 
    age; eternity; fortune, fate; chance, adverse fortune, misfortune, calamity, 
    adversity; danger;--custom, habit, mode, manner; care, solicitude; the world'. 
    (Platts p.541)
interpretation: In the world, a person experiences only two conditions: sorrow and happiness. He says that, 'I have formed an estimate of the persistence/faithfulness of their duration. My experience is that intoxication and joy lasts only for a very little while the  limb-breakingness and misery of the hangover that follows it is lifelong. The gist is that in the world there is little happiness and much grief. (58)
sherText:
dekhī vafā-e furṣat-e ranj-o-nishāt̤-e 
      dahr

      ḳhamyāzah yak darāzī-e ʿumr-e ḳhumār thā

firstVerse:
dil guzar-gāh-e ḳhayāl-e mai-o-sāġhar hī
sahī
secondVerse: gar nafas jādah-e sar-manzil-e taqvī nah huʾā
engTranslation:
1) let the heart be a roadway of the thought of wine 
      and wineglass at least

      2) if the breath didn't become a path to the destination
of piety
notes:
sahī : 'emphat. part. Yea, verily, indeed, 
    true enough, forsooth; just so; very well, so be it, let it be; just'. (Platts 
    p.707)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {9}
sherText:
dil guzar-gāh-e ḳhayāl-e mai-o-sāġhar hī
sahī

gar nafas jādah-e sar-manzil-e taqvī nah huʾā

firstVerse:
shauq hai sāmāñ-t̤arāz-e nāzish-e 
      arbāb-e ʿajz

      żarrah ṣaḥrā-dast-gāh-o-qat̤rah daryā-āshnā
engTranslation:
1) ardor is the equipment-adorner of the glory/boasting/coquetry 
      of the lords/possessors of weakness

      2) the sand-grain is a desert-{power/knowledge/'hand-place'} and the 
      drop is a sea-{friend/swimmer}
notes:
āshnā : 'A friend, companion, comrade, 
    acquaintance; swimming, floating; a swimmer'. (Steingass p.66)
interpretation:
He says, the property of the lords of weakness-- that is, 
    humans who are made of dust-- is the coquetry of passion, by reason of which 
    a nothing of a sand-grain becomes the desert and an insubstantial drop becomes 
    the sea. The meaning is that humans who are made of dust and have an insubstantial 
    existence, make such progress that... they obtain access to the Exalted Divine 
    Court, thanks to passion. (78)
sherText:
shauq hai sāmāñ-t̤arāz-e nāzish-e 
      arbāb-e ʿajz

      żarrah ṣaḥrā-dast-gāh-o-qat̤rah daryā-āshnā

engTranslation:
1) a loser/'trick-eater' through deceit/beguilement, 
      is the taste/relish of the people of insight

      2) the gathering was eager/'hot' for/with the amazement of 
      existence and manifestation/display
notes:
hangāmah : 'A convention, an assembly, 
    a meeting; a crowd; --noise, tumult, commotion, confusion, uproar; sedition, 
    disturbance, disorder'. (Platts p.1238)
interpretation: He says that the people of insight, who are eagerly searching for the truth/reality of this gathering/turmoil of existence, have in reality fallen into a trick/deceit. The heat/enthusiasm of the gathering/turmoil of existence is only the running in circles of amazement at existence and nonexistence. (29)
sherText:
bāzī-ḳhvur-e fareb hai ahl-e naz̤ar kā 
      żauq

      hangāmah garm-e ḥairat-e būd-o-namūd thā

firstVerse:
surmah-e muft-e
              naz̤ar hūñ mirī qīmat yih hai

              kih rahe chashm-e ḳharīdār pah iḥsāñ merā
engTranslation:
1) I am free collyrium for the
          sight/gaze, my price/worth is this--

          2) that my kindness/favor/obligation would remain on the eyes
          of the purchaser
notes:
iḥsān : 'Doing that which
        is good; beneficence, benefaction, benevolent action, benefit,
        favour, kindness, good offices, obligation conferred'. (Platts
        p.29)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {44}
sherText:
surmah-e muft-e
              naz̤ar hūñ mirī qīmat yih hai

              kih rahe chashm-e ḳharīdār pah iḥsāñ merā

firstVerse: balā-e jāñ hai ġhālib us kī har bāt
secondVerse: ʿibārat kyā ishārat kyā adā kyā
engTranslation: 1) it's a mortal disaster, Ghalib-- her every word/speech/circumstance
notes:
bāt : 'Speech, language, word, saying, 
    conversation, talk, gossip, report, discourse, news, tale, story, account; 
    thing, affair, matter, business, concern, fact, case, circumstance, occurrence, 
    object, particular, article, proposal, aim, cause, question, subject'. (Platts 
    p.117)
interpretation:
The meaning is: Oh Ghalib! every single bāt of hers is deadly, whether it be expression, or gestures, 
    or style. (46)
sherText:
balā-e jāñ hai ġhālib us kī har bāt

ʿibārat kyā ishārat kyā adā kyā

firstVerse:
dost ġham-ḳhvārī meñ merī saʿī 
      farmāveñge kyā
secondVerse:
zaḳhm ke bharne talak nāḳhun nah baṛh
jāveñge kyā
engTranslation:
1a) what help, in {my affliction / sympathy with me}, 
      will friends attempt to bestow?

      1b) will friends attempt to bestow help, in {my affliction / sympathy with 
      me}?

      1c) as if friends will attempt to bestow help, in {my affliction / sympathy 
      with me}!
notes:
talak is an archaic form of tak 
    ; GRAMMAR.
interpretation:
How excellently he has presented the meaning that my friends, 
    in sympathy-- what more can they do than having my nails cut? In the state 
    of madness, I keep scratching the wound and don't let it heal. After the nails 
    are cut, it's hoped that the wound will quickly heal. In opposition to my 
    friends, I'm thinking, by the time the wound heals, my cut nails too will 
    grow, and all their efforts will become useless in a single moment, because 
    I will again deepen the wound. (40)
sherText:
dost ġham-ḳhvārī meñ merī saʿī 
      farmāveñge kyā

      zaḳhm ke bharne talak nāḳhun nah baṛh
jāveñge kyā

firstVerse:
dil nahīñ tujh ko dikhātā varnah dāġhoñ kī
bahār
secondVerse:
us chirāġhāñ kā karūñ kyā
kār-farmā jal gayā
engTranslation:
1) {there is / I have} no heart, otherwise I would 
      have shown you a flourishing/springtime of wounds
notes:
chirāġhāñ : 'Lamps; lights; a display 
    of lamps, a general illumination'. (Platts p.428)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {5}
sherText:
dil nahīñ tujh ko dikhātā varnah dāġhoñ kī
bahār
us chirāġhāñ kā karūñ kyā
kār-farmā jal gayā

secondVerse:
ham ne vaḥshat-kadah-e 
      bazm-e jahāñ meñ jūñ shamʿa

      shulah-e ʿishq ko apnā sar-o-sāmāñ samjhā
engTranslation:
1) we, in the desolation-chamber of the 
      gathering of the world, like a candle

      2) considered the flame of passion to be our equipment/effects
notes:
bazm : 'Assembly, company, party, entertainment, 
    feast, banquet'. (Platts p.154)
interpretation:
What is the equipment of a candle? Only a flame. We too understood 
    it to be the equipment of our life in the desolation-filled gathering of the 
    world, to keep burning with the flame of passion. Besides this, we had nothing, 
    nor did we need anything. Although finally this flame will extinguish our 
    very self, the way the flame of a candle devours the candle.
sherText:
ham ne vaḥshat-kadah-e 
      bazm-e jahāñ meñ jūñ shamʿa

      shulah-e ʿishq ko apnā sar-o-sāmāñ samjhā

firstVerse:
hamah nā-umīdī hamah bad-gumānī

      maiñ dil hūñ fareb-e vafā-ḳhvurdagāñ kā
engTranslation:
1) all/entirely hopelessness, all/entirely distrust/suspicion--

      2) I am the heart of those who have swallowed/'eaten' the deceit/delusion 
      of faithfulness
notes:
fareb : 'Deception, deceit, fraud, trick, 
    duplicity, treachery, imposture, delusion, fallacy; allurement, beguilement, 
    &c. ... fareb-ḳhvurdah , part. adj. Deceived, cheated, 
    duped, gulled'. (Platts p.780)
interpretation: Urdu text: Vajid 1902 {37}
sherText:
hamah nā-umīdī hamah bad-gumānī

      maiñ dil hūñ fareb-e vafā-ḳhvurdagāñ kā

engTranslation:
1) the house-and-household of lovers is the shop of 
      a fireworks-maker  

      2) when the flame-faced one became eager/'hot' for a spectacle, it burned up
interpretation:
In the shop of a fireworks-maker, if a spark would be touched to it, 
    then everything will explode at once. The state of the property and wealth 
    of lovers too is just like this. The beautiful ones cast a glance in their 
    direction-- and everything burned. It's not as if it would burn by itself! 
    Having fallen into the snare of beautiful ones, the lover himself will become 
    a destroyed house and household. (110)
sherText:
ḳhān-mān-e ʿāshiqāñ dūkān-e ātish-bāz 
      hai

      shuʿlah-rū jab ho gaʾe garm-e tamāshā jal gayā

firstVerse: ḥaif us chār girih kapṛe kī qismat ġhālib
secondVerse:
jis kī qismat meñ ho ʿāshiq kā garebāñ
honā
engTranslation:
1) alas for the 'cutting out'/destiny of that four measures of cloth,
Ghalib

2) in the destiny/'cutting out' of which would be, to be a
lover's collar!
interpretation:
That is, if there's separation, then he himself
tears it; and if there's union, then at the hands of the beloved's
mischievousness it will be torn to shreds.  (18)
sherText:
ḥaif us chār girih kapṛe kī qismat ġhālib
jis kī qismat meñ ho ʿāshiq kā garebāñ
honā

firstVerse: muḥābā kyā hai maiñ ẓāmin idhar dekh
secondVerse: shahīdān-e nigah kā ḳhūñ-bahā kyā
engTranslation:
1) what concern/caution is there? I am responsible-- 
      look this way!
interpretation:
It is contrary to custom for a blood-price to be taken
for martyrs of a glance. So why are you afraid? Cast off fear and look
toward me; if I die, I take responsibility for it, no questions will be
asked of you. The excellence and supremacy with which Mirza Sahib has
presented this theme
is manifest.  (46)
sherText:
muḥābā kyā hai maiñ ẓāmin idhar dekh

shahīdān-e nigah kā ḳhūñ-bahā kyā

firstVerse:
kam jānte the ham bhī ġham-e ʿishq ko par
ab
secondVerse:
dekhā to kam huʾe pah ġham-e rozgār
thā
engTranslation:
1a) we too considered the grief of passion [to be 
      relatively] less/small, but now

      1b) we too knew little of the grief of passion, but now
notes: huʾe pah is an archaic form of hone pah , with the pah of course short for  par (GRAMMAR)
interpretation:
Because of inexperience, like others I too thought that the 
    grief of passion was small. But when I was trapped in that disaster, I became 
    aware of the true state of affairs. That is, the grief of passion, even when 
    it becomes less, turned out to be somewhat more than the whole world's grief. 
    (36)
sherText:
kam jānte the ham bhī ġham-e ʿishq ko par
ab
dekhā to kam huʾe pah ġham-e rozgār
thā

firstVerse: sādagīhā-e tamannā yaʿnī
secondVerse: phir vuh nairang-e naz̤ar yād āyā
engTranslation:
1) simplicities of longing-- that is

      2) again/then that marvel/enchantment/deceit of sight came to mind/recollection
interpretation:
The meaning is that those things that the glance of the beloved 
    said through hints and suggestions, the lover in his simplicity considered 
    as a means to accomplishing his longing-- or rather, he came to believe perfectly 
    in his success. But the result was nothing at all. It became clear that it 
    was a trick of the beloved's glances, but there was a kind of pleasure in 
    them; thus they come to mind again. (67)
sherText:
sādagīhā-e tamannā yaʿnī
phir vuh nairang-e naz̤ar yād āyā

engTranslation:
1a) poverty/'voicelessness'-- the fresh/juicy sound 
      of the melody of fame, Asad

      1b) the fresh/juicy sound of the melody of fame-- poverty/'voicelessness', 
      Asad

      

      2a) the straw-mat was a whole reed-thicket-world [of] loud/lofty noise

      2b) the whole reed-thicket-world [of] loud/lofty noise was a straw mat
notes:
ʿālam : 'The world, the universe; men, 
    people, creatures; regions; kingdom (in comp., e.g. 'vegetable-kingdom'); 
    --age, period, time, season; state, condition, case, circumstances; a state 
    of beauty; a beautiful sight or scene'. (Platts p.757)
interpretation:
The meaning of be-navāʾī is lack 
    of possessions; that is, poverty. The meaning of navā 
    is also 'voice'. Thus, according to the [Indo-Persian dictionary] bahār-e 
    ʿajam , the word be-navāʾī means not only 'poverty' 
    but also 'voicelessness'. In this verse, 'poverty' is intended. 'Voicelessness' 
    is only by way of an īhām 
    ,
sherText:
be-navāʾī tar ṣadā-e naġhmah-e shuhrat 
      asad

      boriyā yak naisitāñ-ʿālam buland āvāzah thā

firstVerse:
jalvah az-baskih taqāẓā-e nigah kartā
hai
secondVerse:
jauhar-e āʾinah bhī chāhe hai
mizhgāñ honā
engTranslation:
1) {since / to such an extent} glory/appearance makes 
      a claim of a look/gaze

      2) even/also the polish-marks on the mirror want to be  eyelashes
interpretation:
Seeing the power of the radiance/appearance of the beloved 
    to create an ardor for sight, even the polish-line on the mirror wants to 
    become an eyelash. That is, if I cannot myself see like the eye of the mirror, 
    then let me become a part of the seer. (41)
sherText:
jalvah az-baskih taqāẓā-e nigah kartā
hai
jauhar-e āʾinah bhī chāhe hai
mizhgāñ honā

engTranslation:
1) Asad 
      is a stranger to coldness/dejection, oh Friendlessness/forlornness

      2) [his] heart, from the style of the warmth/fervor of the people of the 
      world, burned up
notes: jal jānā : '(intens.) To be burnt up, be consumed (with, - se )'. (Platts p.387)
interpretation:
Oh Friendlessness, Asad is now not influenced by dejection. 
    He has seen the warmth and ebullience of the people of the world, and having 
    seen its artificialness and triviality his heart has burned. Now he has arrived 
    beyond the feeling of dejection. (110)
sherText:
hai asad be-gānah-e afsurdagī ay be-kasī

      dil z andāz-e tapāk-e ahl-e dunyā jal gayā
